BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 22, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

NEW ATHLETIC BOARD

HOPKINS DOWNS ST. JOHN'S

GAIL, '12, LACROSSE CAPTAIN

TENNIS TOURNAMENT TODAY

Jack Fulton Was the Only Candidate for
President —Lacrosse Men Prominent on Board.

Black and Blue Players Win Close Game
From Old *Rivals—Squeeze Play
Worked by St. John's.

Dinner Given at Hopkins Club to the
Lacrosse Team—Prospects for
1912 Bright.

A Large List of Entries Has Been
Received—Some Good Matches
Scheduled.

The regular annual election of
officers of the General Athletic Association was held in Hopkins Hall
last Monday, the ith, at 5 o'clock.
In the absence of President Holmes
and Vice-President Hunter, Mr.
George Stewart, the treasurer, presided at the meeting.
Immediately after the meeting
was called to order several candidates had their names scratched
from the ticket, among them Ray
for corresponding secretary, Hunter for president, and Musser,
Easter and Catlin.
Jimmy Hunter declined to run
for President, and, consequently,
Fulton got the office, being the only
candidate. Johnny Holmes, who
had been president for four years,
declined to run because he will be
graduate manager next year and
will, accordingly, have his hands
full.
Dr. Radcliffe, the• alumni delegate, was unanimously ye-elected.
The closest race was that for corresponding secretary between Freddie
Lee and Wagner. It was not until
the final fifteen votes were counted
that the outcome was decided.
Getz was elected junior delegate.
He ran against Pieper, Ray and
Gillet, all of whom put up a strong
fight.
Walter Sutton, goal-keeper on
the lacrosse team, was elected sophomore delegate. He ran against
Hollyday and J. L. Dorsey.
The results were:
President—J. Fulton.
Vice-President--J. F. Hunter.
Corresponding Secretary—F. C.
Lee.
Alumni Delegate—Dr. Radcliffe.
Medical School Delegate — S.
Horrax.
Graduate Delegate—E. D. Hubburt.
Senior Delegates—W. Gail and
G. Schmeisser.
Junior Delegate—C. L. Getz.
Sophomore Delegate—NV. Sutton.

For the second time this year
Hopkins defeated its old rival, St.
John's, when last Saturday, at
Homewood, the Black and Blue
nine won a well-earned victory over
the much-touted team from Annapolis by the close score of 3 to 2.
The result of the game not only
justified the existence of the Hopkins nine, but also made a very appropriate conclusion to a season
which, considering the fact that it
was the first time Hopkins has had
a nine in four years, was remarkably successful.
Both teams played well and the
game was principally a pitchers'
battle. Tolson was touched up for
ten safeties, but kept them fairly
well scattered, which accounts for
the small score made by Hopkins.
Silvester allowed but two hits,
neither of which were instrumental
in scoring runs.
The feature of the game was the
beautiful squeeze play that St.
John's worked in the second inning
and which netted the visitors their
two runs. Ruhl was the first batter
up and received his base on balls.
Clark popped a fly to Webster.
Thompson was struck on the arm,
sending Ruhl to second. They
worked a double steal successfully.
Steele, who was at the bat, was
given the signal for a squeeze play,
and Ruhl made a dash for the plate
as Silvester started to throw the
ball. Steele succeeded in connecting with the shoot for a neat little
bunt, which scored Ruhl. Steele
was thrown out at first, but in the
meantime Thompson had also
scored. This ended St. John's run
getting for the rest of the game.
Hopkins scored two runs in the
first inning. Smith was struck by
a pitched ball and was given his
base. He stole second and crossed
the plate on Shaw's timely single.
Shaw also stole second and reached
home on Pieper's single. The winning run was made in the eighth
session. Shaw connected with the
ball safely for the third time. His
hit was good for two bases and he

William Gail was elected captain
of the 1912 lacrosse team last Tuesday night. The election took place
at a reception given to this year's
team by ex-Captain Eddie Hulburt
at the Hopkins Club.
The dinner was voted by all who
attended as one of the most pleasant ever held. The speakers, particularly Coach Raleigh, excelled
themselves. At the dinner it was
decided by this year's team that
they would give a banner to the
winner of the series of lacrosse
games between the Sophomores
and Freshmen.
There is no question but that the
election will meet with the approval
of every undergraduate. It would
be a difficult thing to point to any
one man on our champion team and
say: "He is the best man." They
were all the best men. That's why
we won the championship. Every
man on the team played not to gain
individual distinction, but to bring
the team victory, whatever the cost
to himself. But Gail has been one
of the best all-around players on
the team. He was always available
for any position which had to be
filled on short notice. Moreover,
his experience of three years on the
'Varsity team is of great importance. And with all the material
that is now in sight there is no reason why another championship banner should not be hung up in the
trophy room next year.

The third annual tennis tournament, open to all members of the
University, starts today. There is
a large list of entries, among them
some vet), good players, so that
there is no doubt that the gallery
will see some good tennis at Homewood this week. The matches will
all be called at 5 o'clock. The drawing, which was made this morning, will be posted in the basement
of McCoy Hall and out at Homewood. Handsome prizes will be
awarded to the winner and runnerup and winner of consolation in the
singles, and to the winners and runners-up in the doubles. As the
doubles entries do not close until
Wednesday, it is hoped that a large
number will still enter in that event.
The tournament has been arranged
by the following committee: Donald K. Belt, chairman; Edmund B.
Clary and H. E. Corner.
Tennis Team Wins.

At Westminster last Wednesday
the Varsity tennis team defeated the
Western Maryland College team by
the score of 4 to 2. The Hopkins
team has had sufficient practice lately to put the men in good trim, so
that they ought to make a good
showing against the University of
Pennsylvania on May 31. The
match will be played on the Pennsylvania courts.
The results of the match last
Wednesday were:

Dr. Mast Appointed to Faculty.

SINGLES.

Dr. Samuel 0. Mast lias been
appointed associate professor of
zoology in the Johns Hopkins University, his duties to begin September I, 1911. Dr. Mast is a native
of Alichigan and a graduate of the
University of Michigan in 1899. In
1905 he received the degree of doctor of philosophy from Harvard
University. He held a Johnston
scholarship in the Johns Hopkins
University during tlit year 1907-08,
and since 1908 he has been a member of the faculty of Goucher College, holding at present the professorship of botany. He has published many papers in technical scientific journals, and is author of a
book entitled "Light and the Behavior of Organisms."

M.), 8-6, 7-5.

(W. M.), 6-1, 6-4.

9-7.
Belt and Springer (Hopkins) defeated
Brown and Colburn (W. M.),6-2,6-1.

A debate was held in French at
Brown University last week. The
subject was the comparative merits
of French and English as an international language.

Dr. Wilfred R Mustard, collegiate professor of Latin, will
spend the summer in Canada fishing and hunting. For the last few
years Dr. Mustard has been spending his summers in the Latin countries of Europe. This summer,
however, he will revisit his native
land, Canada.
H. C. Rentschler, Ph. D.'08, has
been promoted to assistant professor of physics at the University of
Missouri.

which makes it all the more remarkable that the articles are all interestingly written in good, clear English. In point of fact, The College

And flung them all about us there
In the loud noonday's heat and glare :
Gold tresses far too fine to wind
And brown with copper and entwined,
And black coils black as all my mind.
In the low stifling armory
Whence we could hear, but might not
flee
The roar of that cngirdling sea,
Whose waves were helmet crests of foes,
Winding the cords we sat in rows,
Beside a mo'und of stringless bows.

Quick as we worked we could not make
Strings fast as bowmen came to take
Fresh bows; and, oh, the grinding ache
Of hearts and fingers; maid and slave
And princess, we toiled to save
Home that already was our grave.

Harsh and unevenly outside
Shields clanged, men called, and cursed
and cried;
And when again the latch was tried
My knife lay somewhere .on the floor.
Alas! I found it not before
Three armored foemen burst the door.

Evidently this verse is plain
enough to be understood, and, what
is equally welcome, it has something
to say that is worth being understood. It is distinctly not poetry of
Mr. Burton's variety. Mr. White
has also written some significant
blank verse and made several noteworthy experiments in meter. The
"Narrative Lyrics" contains examples of trochaic pentameter, trochaic
trimeter, terza rima and several new
combinations of more familiar measures. How he succeeds in some of
these experiments can be seen from
the following lines from "Talith:"
In the chapel all the cressets were on
fire,
But the mourners all save one had long
departed,
For the Queen of Rhampsinitos, King of
Egypt,
Lay there silent, and he watched his
dead and sorrowed.

Altogether Mr.White is a healthy
figure in literature in these days
when most poetry consists of moonshine dyed the color of obscurity.
It is only in verse of the kind which
he seeks to give us that the health
and vigor of English or any other
literature can be preserved. He deserves to he better known at the
Hopkins.
JOHN SHAM DICKINSON.

L. A. Reymann, '99, Dies.

Lawrence A. Reymann, '99, a
prominent attorney of Wheeling,
W. Va., died of scarlet fever on
May 8. Mr. Reymann was one of
the best-known citizens of Wheeling, which was his home all his life
With the exception of the years spent
at college. Subsequent to his graduation from Hopkins Mr. Reymann
went to Europe and studied for a
year at a German university. On
his return he went to the University of Virginia, where he received
his B. LL. degree. In 1904, at the
age of 25 years, he was nominated
for attorney general of West Virginia on the Democratic ticket. He
was one of the delegates-at-large
from West Virginia to the national
convention in 1908. For a rnan of
iii years Mr. Reymann had attained unusual prominence in his
community.

Graduate Students' Baseball.

For the fourth consecutive year
the students in history and economics have won the championship
at baseball in the graduate department. Last week and the week before games were played between
the History team, the Classical team
and the Chemistry team. Both of
these resulted in victory for the Historicals. Against the Classical team
the score was 25 to 20, while in the
Chemistry game the score was 9 to
8 after a ten-inning struggle. Dr.
Mago'ffin is, as usual, the old standby of the Historicals.

Sophomores Victorious.

In the second half the Sophomore
attack braced up and there was more
work for the Freshmen's defense.
At one time the Sophomores really
outplayed the Freshmen. Niles, the
Sophomores' point, was put out of
the game for three minutes for
needless slugging with his stick.
This gave the Freshmen an odd
man with the ball right in front of
the Sophomores' goal. And yet, in
spite of all this, the Sophomore attack rushed the ball right up to the
Freshmen's goal. By the time they
were stopped and the ball had been
taken back up the field Niles was
back in the game. At the end of
sixteen minutes of play Randolph,
who was playing outhome for the
Sophomores, recovered the ball
from a scrimmage and shot the only
goal scored.
Sears, goalkeeper for the Sophomores, played a fine game. The
Freshmen had more shots for goal
than the Sophomores did, and several times had there been an inferior man at goal these shots would
have scored.
For the Freshmen White, Riley,
Leibensperger and Wilkens played
a fine game. Wilkens at point was
particularly good and several times
ran the whole length of the field
with the ball.

The Sophomores last Friday defeated the Freshmen in one of the
hardest-fought lacrosse games seen
at Homewood this year by the score
of i to o. The feature of the game
was the fact that the teams were
so evenly matched. It was anybody's game all the way through,
and it was only the one goal that
was shot four minutes before the
end of the second half that finally
decided the contest.
In the first half the ball was in
the Sophomores' territory most of
the time. Occasionally one of the
Sophomore defense men would
bring the ball down the field toward the Freshmen goal, but would
usually be stopped before he got
close enough to do any damage.
After about fifteen minutes of playing White, of the Freshmen, shot
a goal, but because he was in the
"creese" when he made the shot the
point did not count.

Mrs. Mary C. Browne, the wife
of Dr. William Hand Browne,
emeritus professor of English literature, died at her home, in Sherwood, on May 17. She was 79
years of age.

TENNIS TOURNAMENT TODAY

Jack Fulton Was the Only Candidate for
President —Lacrosse Men Prominent on Board.

Black and Blue Players Win Close Game
From Old *Rivals—Squeeze Play
Worked by St. John's.

Dinner Given at Hopkins Club to the
Lacrosse Team—Prospects for
1912 Bright.

A Large List of Entries Has Been
Received—Some Good Matches
Scheduled.

The regular annual election of
officers of the General Athletic Association was held in Hopkins Hall
last Monday, the ith, at 5 o'clock.
In the absence of President Holmes
and Vice-President Hunter, Mr.
George Stewart, the treasurer, presided at the meeting.
Immediately after the meeting
was called to order several candidates had their names scratched
from the ticket, among them Ray
for corresponding secretary, Hunter for president, and Musser,
Easter and Catlin.
Jimmy Hunter declined to run
for President, and, consequently,
Fulton got the office, being the only
candidate. Johnny Holmes, who
had been president for four years,
declined to run because he will be
graduate manager next year and
will, accordingly, have his hands
full.
Dr. Radcliffe, the• alumni delegate, was unanimously ye-elected.
The closest race was that for corresponding secretary between Freddie
Lee and Wagner. It was not until
the final fifteen votes were counted
that the outcome was decided.
Getz was elected junior delegate.
He ran against Pieper, Ray and
Gillet, all of whom put up a strong
fight.
Walter Sutton, goal-keeper on
the lacrosse team, was elected sophomore delegate. He ran against
Hollyday and J. L. Dorsey.
The results were:
President—J. Fulton.
Vice-President--J. F. Hunter.
Corresponding Secretary—F. C.
Lee.
Alumni Delegate—Dr. Radcliffe.
Medical School Delegate — S.
Horrax.
Graduate Delegate—E. D. Hubburt.
Senior Delegates—W. Gail and
G. Schmeisser.
Junior Delegate—C. L. Getz.
Sophomore Delegate—NV. Sutton.

For the second time this year
Hopkins defeated its old rival, St.
John's, when last Saturday, at
Homewood, the Black and Blue
nine won a well-earned victory over
the much-touted team from Annapolis by the close score of 3 to 2.
The result of the game not only
justified the existence of the Hopkins nine, but also made a very appropriate conclusion to a season
which, considering the fact that it
was the first time Hopkins has had
a nine in four years, was remarkably successful.
Both teams played well and the
game was principally a pitchers'
battle. Tolson was touched up for
ten safeties, but kept them fairly
well scattered, which accounts for
the small score made by Hopkins.
Silvester allowed but two hits,
neither of which were instrumental
in scoring runs.
The feature of the game was the
beautiful squeeze play that St.
John's worked in the second inning
and which netted the visitors their
two runs. Ruhl was the first batter
up and received his base on balls.
Clark popped a fly to Webster.
Thompson was struck on the arm,
sending Ruhl to second. They
worked a double steal successfully.
Steele, who was at the bat, was
given the signal for a squeeze play,
and Ruhl made a dash for the plate
as Silvester started to throw the
ball. Steele succeeded in connecting with the shoot for a neat little
bunt, which scored Ruhl. Steele
was thrown out at first, but in the
meantime Thompson had also
scored. This ended St. John's run
getting for the rest of the game.
Hopkins scored two runs in the
first inning. Smith was struck by
a pitched ball and was given his
base. He stole second and crossed
the plate on Shaw's timely single.
Shaw also stole second and reached
home on Pieper's single. The winning run was made in the eighth
session. Shaw connected with the
ball safely for the third time. His
hit was good for two bases and he

William Gail was elected captain
of the 1912 lacrosse team last Tuesday night. The election took place
at a reception given to this year's
team by ex-Captain Eddie Hulburt
at the Hopkins Club.
The dinner was voted by all who
attended as one of the most pleasant ever held. The speakers, particularly Coach Raleigh, excelled
themselves. At the dinner it was
decided by this year's team that
they would give a banner to the
winner of the series of lacrosse
games between the Sophomores
and Freshmen.
There is no question but that the
election will meet with the approval
of every undergraduate. It would
be a difficult thing to point to any
one man on our champion team and
say: "He is the best man." They
were all the best men. That's why
we won the championship. Every
man on the team played not to gain
individual distinction, but to bring
the team victory, whatever the cost
to himself. But Gail has been one
of the best all-around players on
the team. He was always available
for any position which had to be
filled on short notice. Moreover,
his experience of three years on the
'Varsity team is of great importance. And with all the material
that is now in sight there is no reason why another championship banner should not be hung up in the
trophy room next year.

The third annual tennis tournament, open to all members of the
University, starts today. There is
a large list of entries, among them
some vet), good players, so that
there is no doubt that the gallery
will see some good tennis at Homewood this week. The matches will
all be called at 5 o'clock. The drawing, which was made this morning, will be posted in the basement
of McCoy Hall and out at Homewood. Handsome prizes will be
awarded to the winner and runnerup and winner of consolation in the
singles, and to the winners and runners-up in the doubles. As the
doubles entries do not close until
Wednesday, it is hoped that a large
number will still enter in that event.
The tournament has been arranged
by the following committee: Donald K. Belt, chairman; Edmund B.
Clary and H. E. Corner.
Tennis Team Wins.

At Westminster last Wednesday
the Varsity tennis team defeated the
Western Maryland College team by
the score of 4 to 2. The Hopkins
team has had sufficient practice lately to put the men in good trim, so
that they ought to make a good
showing against the University of
Pennsylvania on May 31. The
match will be played on the Pennsylvania courts.
The results of the match last
Wednesday were:

Dr. Mast Appointed to Faculty.

SINGLES.

Dr. Samuel 0. Mast lias been
appointed associate professor of
zoology in the Johns Hopkins University, his duties to begin September I, 1911. Dr. Mast is a native
of Alichigan and a graduate of the
University of Michigan in 1899. In
1905 he received the degree of doctor of philosophy from Harvard
University. He held a Johnston
scholarship in the Johns Hopkins
University during tlit year 1907-08,
and since 1908 he has been a member of the faculty of Goucher College, holding at present the professorship of botany. He has published many papers in technical scientific journals, and is author of a
book entitled "Light and the Behavior of Organisms."

Brown University last week. The
subject was the comparative merits

And flung them all about us there
In the loud noonday's heat and glare :
Gold tresses far too fine to wind
And brown with copper and entwined,
And black coils black as all my mind.
In the low stifling armory
Whence we could hear, but might not
flee
The roar of that cngirdling sea,
Whose waves were helmet crests of foes,
Winding the cords we sat in rows,
Beside a mo'und of stringless bows.

Quick as we worked we could not make
Strings fast as bowmen came to take
Fresh bows; and, oh, the grinding ache
Of hearts and fingers; maid and slave
And princess, we toiled to save
Home that already was our grave.

Harsh and unevenly outside
Shields clanged, men called, and cursed
and cried;
And when again the latch was tried
My knife lay somewhere .on the floor.
Alas! I found it not before
Three armored foemen burst the door.

Evidently this verse is plain
enough to be understood, and, what
is equally welcome, it has something
to say that is worth being understood. It is distinctly not poetry of
Mr. Burton's variety. Mr. White
has also written some significant
blank verse and made several noteworthy experiments in meter. The
"Narrative Lyrics" contains examples of trochaic pentameter, trochaic
trimeter, terza rima and several new
combinations of more familiar measures. How he succeeds in some of
these experiments can be seen from
the following lines from "Talith:"
In the chapel all the cressets were on
fire,
But the mourners all save one had long
departed,
For the Queen of Rhampsinitos, King of
Egypt,
Lay there silent, and he watched his
dead and sorrowed.

Altogether Mr.White is a healthy
figure in literature in these days
when most poetry consists of moonshine dyed the color of obscurity.
It is only in verse of the kind which
he seeks to give us that the health
and vigor of English or any other
literature can be preserved. He deserves to he better known at the
Hopkins.
JOHN SHAM DICKINSON.

L. A. Reymann, '99, Dies.

Lawrence A. Reymann, '99, a
prominent attorney of Wheeling,
W. Va., died of scarlet fever on
May 8. Mr. Reymann was one of
the best-known citizens of Wheeling, which was his home all his life
With the exception of the years spent
at college. Subsequent to his graduation from Hopkins Mr. Reymann
went to Europe and studied for a
year at a German university. On
his return he went to the University of Virginia, where he received
his B. LL. degree. In 1904, at the
age of 25 years, he was nominated
for attorney general of West Virginia on the Democratic ticket. He
was one of the delegates-at-large
from West Virginia to the national
convention in 1908. For a rnan of
iii years Mr. Reymann had attained unusual prominence in his
community.

Graduate Students' Baseball.

For the fourth consecutive year
the students in history and economics have won the championship
at baseball in the graduate department. Last week and the week before games were played between
the History team, the Classical team
and the Chemistry team. Both of
these resulted in victory for the Historicals. Against the Classical team
the score was 25 to 20, while in the
Chemistry game the score was 9 to
8 after a ten-inning struggle. Dr.
Mago'ffin is, as usual, the old standby of the Historicals.
The team was constituted as follows:
Catch—Wolfe.
First Base—Stockton.
Second Base—Swift.
Shortstop—Kraeger.
Third Base—Perce.
Right Field—Magoffin, Johnson.
Center Field—Kelly.
Left FieldT—Peake.
Pitch—Russel (captain), Magoffin.

Sophomores Victorious.

In the second half the Sophomore
attack braced up and there was more
work for the Freshmen's defense.
At one time the Sophomores really
outplayed the Freshmen. Niles, the
Sophomores' point, was put out of
the game for three minutes for
needless slugging with his stick.
This gave the Freshmen an odd
man with the ball right in front of
the Sophomores' goal. And yet, in
spite of all this, the Sophomore attack rushed the ball right up to the
Freshmen's goal. By the time they
were stopped and the ball had been
taken back up the field Niles was
back in the game. At the end of
sixteen minutes of play Randolph,
who was playing outhome for the
Sophomores, recovered the ball
from a scrimmage and shot the only
goal scored.
Sears, goalkeeper for the Sophomores, played a fine game. The
Freshmen had more shots for goal
than the Sophomores did, and several times had there been an inferior man at goal these shots would
have scored.
For the Freshmen White, Riley,
Leibensperger and Wilkens played
a fine game. Wilkens at point was
particularly good and several times
ran the whole length of the field
with the ball.

The Sophomores last Friday defeated the Freshmen in one of the
hardest-fought lacrosse games seen
at Homewood this year by the score
of i to o. The feature of the game
was the fact that the teams were
so evenly matched. It was anybody's game all the way through,
and it was only the one goal that
was shot four minutes before the
end of the second half that finally
decided the contest.
In the first half the ball was in
the Sophomores' territory most of
the time. Occasionally one of the
Sophomore defense men would
bring the ball down the field toward the Freshmen goal, but would
usually be stopped before he got
close enough to do any damage.
After about fifteen minutes of playing White, of the Freshmen, shot
a goal, but because he was in the
"creese" when he made the shot the
point did not count.

Mrs. Mary C. Browne, the wife
of Dr. William Hand Browne,
emeritus professor of English literature, died at her home, in Sherwood, on May 17. She was 79
years of age.
